name: fibre production, kenaf, retting | stalk | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20638/documentation

In practice, kenaf retting is very similar to jute retting. This activity is approximated by the jute retting and involves immersion of the bundles of kenaf into stagnant water in the jute cultivation field, tanks, ponds, ditches etc., or in slowly flowing clear water in canals, rivulets, rivers etc. After several days of immersion, the kenaf fibre gets loosen from the stalk and is extracted from the stalk which becomes the byproduct.;This dataset serves as the transformation process of kenaf plant to fibre. 

The activity starts with the immersion of the plant bundles into the water.

The activity ends with the extraction of the kenaf fibres from the retted plants. It is done manually by hand. The kenaf Fibre is then gets dried in the sun.
category: C:Manufacturing/13:Manufacture of textiles/131:Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles/1311:Preparation and spinning of textile fibres

processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataste is extrapolated from jute retting. Uncertainty was adjusted accordingly.

exchanges.description: the by-product of the process, is here approximated by stalk.

flow.name: stalk
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/13:Manufacture of textiles/131:Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles/1311:Preparation and spinning of textile fibres

exchanges.description: 170 kgs of water converted to m3. No wastewater output is considere as the retting process is usually accomplished on jute growing fields or in canals and the wastewater either gets diluted or washed away
sum of electricity used for retting water extraction and water ribbioning
